Deciding Between Visual Diff and Visual Merge

Visual Diff and Visual Merge are both utilities that manage changes between revisions of files. They are included in the Windows client and on the Cross-Platform client when it is installed on a Windows operating system.

Despite the fact that these utilities look similar, they have different capabilities.

Visual Diff is basically a text comparison utility. Using Visual Diff, you can quickly compare two different revisions of a text file or two similar text files, whether they are located in the application or on your workstation. The files are matched against each another and no other information about the files (such as their properties) is involved.

Visual Merge allows you merge two text files that are different but based on the same application revision. It is typically used in the following situation: Two team members have checked out the same revision of a file and have changed their working files. One person checks in the file, creating a new revision and changing the status of the other person's file to Merge. If the second person checks in his or her file, it will override the first set of changes, now the tip revision. With Visual Merge, however, the changes to the file can be combined, so that no work is lost.

Therefore, to make a simple comparison of two text files, use Visual Diff. To consolidate two edited versions of the same file after one of them has been checked in, use Visual Merge.
